item.title: Â∞ºÂÖãÊñØÁêÉËø∑Âú®ÂèØÊÄïÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∫åÂú∫ÊØîËµõËæìÁªôÊ≠•Ë°åËÄÖÈòüÂêéË¢´Ê∑òÊ±∞Âá∫Â±ÄÔºå‰∏≠Â§ÆÂÖ¨Âõ≠ËßÇÁúãÊ¥æÂØπÁöÑÊ≤âÈó∑Â§©Ê∞îÔºö ‚ÄúÈùûÂ∏∏‰ª§‰∫∫ÈúáÊÉä‚Äù | Knicks fans washed out after dreadful Game 2 loss to Pacers, dreary weather at Central Park watch party: ‚ÄòVery crushing‚Äô
item.description:
If only the Knicks could make it rain like this.

Scores of Knicks fans subjected themselves to stormy weather at the Central Park fan watch party Friday night that was made all the more dreadful by the team‚Äôs loss to the Indiana Pacers in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference Finals.

Over 1,000 Knicks faithful walked away from the SummerStage with sopping socks and dashed hopes as the hometown team dropped another game at Madison Square Garden ‚Äî but some fans still believe the sun will come out tomorrow, kind of.

‚ÄúI have faith, kind of,‚Äù Upper West Sider Shohan Zucker, 18, told The Post, adding, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not feeling great.

‚ÄúBrunson can‚Äôt be our only savior. We have to have other people making stops and getting shots.‚Äù

Other fans were ready to come to grips with squandering home court advantage and dropping behind two games to a hated archrival.

‚ÄúIt was very crushing,‚Äù Upper East Sider Zephan Rya, 18, said.

During the watch party, fans stayed hopeful despite the bad weather, worse play from the Knicks and technical problems at SummerStage that lasted 10 minutes during the second quarter.

‚ÄúFix the sound! Fix the sound!,‚Äù fans chanted before it was remedied.

Down the stretch, poncho-clad hoopheads mustered chants of ‚ÄúDEFENSE!‚Äù ‚Äî cheering on star Brunson and longest-tenured Knick Mitchell Robinson, who elated the crowd with his standout performance in the losing effort.

After the game, fans streamed out of the park with rain down their backs and tears down their cheeks.

This wasn‚Äôt the only outdoor watch party on Friday, as Citi Field threw the Knicks game on the jumbotron during a rain delay in the Mets game against the Los Angeles Dodgers, according to the Amazins‚Äô X account.

The Knicks fan watch parties were moved to the bigger SummerStage venue after last week‚Äôs Game 6 victory over the Boston Celtics ‚Äî an elation that now seems to be from a different season entirely.

After that win, fans turned Seventh Avenue into Knicks Valhalla, climbing poles, lighting Celtics jerseys on fire and hectoring a Pacers fan ‚Äî who will be Pacers star Tyrese Haliburton‚Äôs guest in Indiana for Game 3.

The Knicks now travel to Indiana to play at the Fieldhouse in Game 3 on Sunday night.
item.author: Haley Brown, Shane Galvin

item.title: ËØàÈ™óËÄÖÊ≠£Âú®‰ΩøÁî®‰∫∫Â∑•Êô∫ËÉΩÂ∞ÜÂèóÂÆ≥ËÄÖ‰ªéÊï∞Áôæ‰∏á‰∫∫‰∏≠Ëß£ÊïëÂá∫Êù•Ôºö‰ª•‰∏ãÊòØÂ¶Ç‰Ωï‰øùÊä§Ëá™Â∑±ÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ï | Scammers are using AI to bilk victims out of millions: Here‚Äôs how to protect yourself
item.description:
This is no way to keep up with grandma.

Cruel scammers are cheating elderly people out of millions of dollars with a new high tech scam that uses AI to find their grandchildren‚Äôs voices on TikTok and then use the sounds to make phony phone calls designed to trick the seniors, cops on Long Island warned Friday.

The scam involves criminals finding a vulnerable and elderly person with grandkids ‚Äî then scouring social media sites like TikTok for videos of the young people speaking.

They then use voice-cloning software and spoofed phone numbers to make panicked calls pretending to be that grandchild, claiming they‚Äôve been arrested or hurt and urgently need bail money or medical funds.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre always trying to stay a step ahead,‚Äù Suffolk County Police Commissioner Kevin Catalina told The Post on Friday.

Catalina confirmed the department has been seeing a growing number of these cases, and said the software criminals are using can perfectly emulate someone else‚Äôs voice ‚Äî often fooling the area‚Äôs vulnerable and elderly population.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs often times a grandchild scheme we‚Äôre seeing, where the individual will call and say that they are in some kind of trouble that requires money,‚Äù Catalina said.

Police said victims have been duped into forking over thousands of dollars in cash and wire transfers ‚Äî thinking they‚Äôre rescuing a loved one when in fact they‚Äôre being scammed by a synthetic voice and a criminal on the other end of the line.

Catalina said the department has seen an uptick in these types of scams in recent months and warned the public to stay vigilant, especially when receiving emotional pleas involving money and secrecy.

He advised families to establish a ‚Äúsafe word‚Äù in case of emergencies, and to reach out to the person they are claiming to be after receiving the call to confirm directly before transferring any money.

As for the scammers, Catalina warned that the department is making these crimes a high priority given the large amount of cases.

‚ÄúIf we find the individuals who do this, who know exactly who they‚Äôre stealing from, we will prosecute you to the fullest ‚Äî these crimes are a priority to us and we‚Äôre gonna make sure that we get to the bottom of this,‚Äù Catalina said.

In 2023, over 3,000 scams were reported on Long Island ‚Äî resulting in over $126 million stolen from mostly senior citizens, according to the most recent data from AARP.

Nearly $74 million was stolen from Nassau, and almost $54 million was taken in Suffolk that year alone.

And Catalina warned it will only get worse as AI continues to progress.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre getting more and more sophisticated, so everybody has to be very careful,‚Äù he said.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: Á∫™ÂøµÊñØÈöÜÂáØÁâπÁê≥Ëàû‰ºöËÆ©ÊÇ£ÊúâÁôåÁóáÁöÑÂ≠©Â≠êÊúâÊú∫‰ºöÂ∫ÜÁ•ùÔºö ‚ÄúÊàëËßâÂæóËá™Â∑±ÂÉè‰∏™Â•≥Áéã‚Äù | Memorial Sloan Kettering prom gives kids with cancer a chance to celebrate: ‚ÄòI feel like a queen‚Äô
item.description:
After being diagnosed with an aggressive and rare carcinoma tumor during her sophomore year in March, 16-year-old Jazzy missed her prom.

But, on Thursday afternoon, the Catskill teen got to walk a red carpet in a pink-beaded ball gown, pose for pics with new bestie and fellow patient Samantha,15, and boogie to ‚ÄúShout‚Äù and ‚ÄúDancing Queen‚Äù with her high school boyfriend Liam.

‚ÄúWe get to have our own little prom here,‚Äù said Jazzy, who is facing hearing loss from her chemotherapy. ‚ÄúWe have a new family here.‚Äù

She was one of about 200 people ‚Äîglammed up patients, families and staffers ‚Äì in attendance at Memorial Sloan Kettering‚Äôs Pediatric Prom, which was held in the transformed West Dining Room inside the renowned hospital.¬†

It was the 35th Pediatric Prom, which started as a small dance party in the hospital unit and has grown to an elaborate ball with fancy dresses, a photo booth, DJs, limos, a milk-and-cookies bar, face paint and lots of dancing.

‚ÄúOur entire team is committed to making it a special and memorable day for everyone involved,‚Äù Rachel Corke, the director of hospital administration for MSK Kids, told The Post.

Against the backdrop of glittery ‚ÄúStarry Night‚Äù themed decorations, guests sipped ginger ale and juice and enjoyed mac and cheese and burgers that even the doctors OK‚Äôed just this once.¬†

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel like a princess ‚Äî I feel like a queen,‚Äù exulted 7-year-old Maya in between bites of freshly popped popcorn from a festive cart. The tiara-clad tot has been battling neuroblastoma since she was 3 and underwent surgery two years ago to remove a tumor.¬†

Hospital staff danced alongside their brave young charges.

‚ÄúThis is everyone‚Äôs favorite day of the year,‚Äù said Melissa Seidner, a 31-year-old administrative supervisor in the pediatric division at MSK. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so fun to see all the patients enjoy themselves. It‚Äôs a nice break from dealing with what we deal with.‚Äù

She wore a jewel green gown that she‚Äôd selected from racks of donated dresses in a repurposed hospital rec room turned into ‚ÄúPromingdale‚Äôs‚Äù by the Society of MSK‚Äôs Children‚Äôs Committee.

Maggie Kraus, a 17-year-old from Westchester who was diagnosed with leukemia this past November, rocked a soft purple frock with matching head scarf as she partied the afternoon away.

‚ÄúI love princess dresses,‚Äù she said, vowing to wear it for her upcoming 18th birthday in July. ‚ÄúI was really nervous I wouldn‚Äôt be able to experience senior prom. But they pulled through.‚Äù

Kraus was set to start her next round of chemo a few hours after prom, but she didn‚Äôt let it ‚Äî and the nausea it would likely bring about ‚Äî take away from her enjoyment of the event.

‚ÄúLet me have fun,‚Äù she said.

As the song ‚ÄúI Will Survive‚Äù played poignantly in the background, the competitive equestrian relayed how her ‚Äúwhole world got turned upside down‚Äù by her recent diagnosis.

Doctors told her she wouldn‚Äôt be able to ride horses for two years.

‚ÄúI proved them wrong and I‚Äôm riding,‚Äù said the fearless teen, who volunteers to work with younger kids on the spectrum. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm super-scared of needles, but I have to get used to it.‚Äù

She shaved off her flowing brown hair ‚Äî which she loved to dye bright colors ‚Äî rather than waiting for the side effects of chemo to cause it to fall out.

‚ÄúI wanted it to be my doing and not the cancer,‚Äù she said.

Pediatric oncologist Dr. Andrew Kung told The Post that the prom exemplifies the philosophy at MSK, whose pediatric cancer center is ranked the best in the country and treats people up to age 40.

‚ÄúThis is one of the most special events for us,‚Äù he said. ‚Äú[We‚Äôre] not just about curing disease but caring for the patient and family.‚Äù

Jon Lyrick was decked out in a show-stopping silver and black suit from Portabella. The 25-year-old from Crown Heights partied with friends as he told The Post that someday he‚Äôd ‚Äúlove to come back to prom as a volunteer.‚Äù

Lyrick, who has undergone two bone marrow transplants, is feeling stronger every day.

‚ÄúI love to have fun,‚Äù he told The Post between songs on the dance floor, where he happily spun around friends and IV poles. ‚ÄúToday is a good day.‚Äù
item.author: Doree Lewak

item.title: Â§ßÂ≠¶ÊØï‰∏öÁîüÂú®ÊØï‰∏öÂÖ∏Á§º‰∏äËØªÂà∞ÂêçÂ≠óÊó∂ÊÑüÂà∞ÈúáÊÉä‚Äî‰∫∫Â∑•Êô∫ËÉΩÔºö ‚ÄúÂ§ö‰πàÁæé‰∏ΩÁöÑ‰∏™‰∫∫È£éÊ†ºÔºÅ‚Äù | College grads shocked as names are read at commencement ‚Äî by AI: ‚ÄòWhat a beautiful personal touch!‚Äô
item.description:
These grads got a robo-sendoff they won‚Äôt forget.

Students at New York City‚Äôs Pace University were left shell-shocked ‚Äî and maybe just a bit shellacked ‚Äî when their recent graduation ceremony featured a synthetic surprise: Their names were read aloud not by a proud professor or a human announcer, but by a voice created by artificial intelligence.

Instead of the usual pomp and circumstance, it was giving ‚Ä¶ self-checkout.

A viral video posted by @therundownai on Instagram shows Pace grads queuing up to have QR codes on their phones scanned ‚Äî a moment some compared to ‚Äúfruit and vegetables at a supermarket checkout‚Äù ‚Äî then hearing their names uttered aloud via disembodied AI over the sound system.

‚ÄúBecause nothing says ‚Äòwe value you‚Äô like a synthetic voice butchering your name after four years and thousands of dollars,‚Äù wrote user @thedeveloperstory on Threads, who also shared the clip. ‚ÄúWhat a beautiful personal touch!‚Äù

The university did give students a heads-up, directing them to a website where they could phonetically spell their names and confirm the pronunciation.

The goal? Accuracy.

The result? A debate hotter than an outdoor, summer cap-and-gown ceremony.

Commenters on both Instagram and Threads were divided. One viewer beneath the IG post deadpanned: ‚ÄúImagine a school that would expel you for using AI to write a paper, but will use AI to read graduate names for them.‚Äù

Another on Threads fumed, ‚ÄúLaziness! Are they really scanning people‚Äôs phones? What the actual F? That guy couldn‚Äôt read their names?‚Äù

One user even lamented the visual awkwardness.

‚ÄúYeah, that looks super cheesy, since it‚Äôs scanned right there in plain view of everyone,‚Äù they wrote. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the whole idea that we know how the sausage gets made, but we don‚Äôt necessarily need to actually see the sausage getting made.‚Äù

Still, others were surprisingly on board.

‚ÄúSame at Northeastern University,‚Äù noted one commenter. ‚ÄúStudents recorded their own name for pronunciation ‚Ä¶ an AI voice read their name.‚Äù

‚ÄúBrilliant!‚Äù another gushed.

Pace isn‚Äôt alone in swapping live talent for machine precision, but for many students, the experience felt more ‚ÄúBlack Mirror‚Äù than commencement celebration.

And it‚Äôs not the first time Gen Z grads have felt overshadowed by AI.

As The Post previously reported, nearly half of Gen Z job seekers now believe their degrees are already obsolete, thanks to AI tools like ChatGPT.¬†

According to a Harris Poll for Indeed, 49% of Gen Z respondents said their college education has lost value in the job market ‚Äî with some now questioning whether it was worth the time and debt.

So, to recap: AI is eating their jobs, undercutting their diplomas ‚Äî and now it‚Äôs stealing their spotlight on graduation day.

Even the good intentions couldn‚Äôt save the vibe. As one Thread user wrote, ‚ÄúWhen I graduated, the person reading out the names had done a run through ‚Ä¶ it didn‚Äôt take that long, and was less weird than showing your phone for them to scan.‚Äù

Perhaps next year‚Äôs grads can just have ChatGPT write their diploma, too.
item.author: Marissa Matozzo

item.title: ÊÑ§ÊÄíÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â¶àÂ¶à‰ª¨ÂèçÂØπÂÑøÁ´•È£üÂìÅ‰∏≠ÁöÑÊØíÁ¥†Ôºö ‚Äú‰øùÊä§‰Ω†ÁöÑÂÆ∂‰∫∫‰∏çÂ∫îËØ•ÈÇ£‰πàÈöæ‚Äù | Furious NYC moms rail against toxins in kid foods: ‚ÄòShouldn‚Äôt be so hard to protect your family‚Äô
item.description:
Tara Ferrara‚Äôs 7-year-old daughter began suffering from a baffling mix of symptoms four years ago ‚Äî nausea, stomach pain and sudden, intense panic that struck without warning.

As dozens of doctors worked to pinpoint the cause, they put the girl on a strict diet low in highly processed foods and free of gluten, dairy, corn, soy and histamines.

For Ferrara, 39, figuring out what her daughter could safely eat was like trying to understand a foreign language.

‚ÄúSometimes I feel like I can‚Äôt work because I literally need to research food,‚Äù Ferrara, a speech and language pathologist from Brooklyn, told The Post.

Ultra-processed foods (UPFs) make up nearly 70% of calories in American kids‚Äô diets ‚Äî and a jaw-dropping new White House report warns they may be fueling the nationwide rise in childhood chronic diseases.

The Make America Healthy Again (MAHA) Commission‚Äôs report marks the Trump administration‚Äôs first major push to confront what it calls a ‚Äúcrisis‚Äù affecting more than 40% of young people across the country.

‚ÄúWe will follow the truth wherever it leads, uphold rigorous science, and drive bold policies that put the health, development and future of every child first,‚Äù HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., said Thursday.

Two New York moms raising children with chronic health issues told The Post that it can be an uphill battle to keep their kids‚Äô diets clean in a country where UPFs dominate supermarket shelves.

UPFs explained

While there‚Äôs no single, universally accepted definition, UPFs are generally packaged, ready-to-eat products that undergo extensive industrial processing to boost their flavor, texture and shelf life.

They‚Äôre often loaded with added sugar, salt, unhealthy fats and refined grains ‚Äî and packed with preservatives, artificial colors, flavors, emulsifiers and stabilizers not commonly used in home cooking.

UPFs usually contain little to no fruits, vegetables or whole grains and are typically low in fiber and other essential nutrients.¬†

Researchers estimate that about 70% of the 300,000-plus branded food products in grocery stores fall into this category.

Food fight

Two years into the strict diet, Ferrara is still navigating the minefield ‚Äî and slip-ups come with serious consequences.

‚Äú[Food] really, really affects her and can trigger a flare-up where she‚Äôs so uncomfortable gut-wise and brain-wise that she can‚Äôt go to school,‚Äù said Ferrara, who co-owns Social City, which provides social support services for children.

One recent mistake? The gluten-free, dairy-free pancakes her daughter eats every morning. Turns out they contain a corn-derived additive called maltodextrin ‚Äî something Ferrara only discovered after calling the manufacturer.

‚ÄúIt was one of the ingredients that my eyes just skipped over, because I don‚Äôt know what that is,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúUnknowingly, every morning I was giving her these gluten-free, dairy-free pancakes that actually have something that is highly inflammatory and ultra-processed.‚Äù

The MAHA report warns that more than 2,500 food additives can be pumped into UPFs ‚Äî all to enhance taste and texture and stretch shelf life.

Some additives have been linked to serious health concerns, including behavioral disorders, metabolic issues and even cancer.

Take Red 40, for example. This food dye is found in popular snacks like Skittles and Doritos, as well as drinks like Pepsi. It has been tied to increased hyperactivity and irritability in children, especially if they have ADHD, and can¬†trigger allergic reactions¬†in others.

Meanwhile, research shows titanium dioxide, found in everything from candies to sauces, may damage cells and even DNA.

Then there are artificial sweeteners like aspartame, sucralose and saccharin, which some studies suggest can disrupt the gut microbiome ‚Äî a key player in metabolism, weight control and blood sugar regulation.

Ferrara‚Äôs younger daughter, 4, doesn‚Äôt have food sensitivities ‚Äî but keeping her diet clean is still a challenge. At school, playdates and other places outside the home, junk food is nearly impossible to avoid.

‚ÄúShe doesn‚Äôt get directly affected immediately after she eats, but I know it‚Äôs doing harm to her over the long term,‚Äù Ferrara said. ‚ÄúJust because it doesn‚Äôt outrightly show on every single person doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not doing the same damage internally.‚Äù

According to the White House report, ultra-processed grains ‚Äî found in cakes, cookies, breads and snack foods ‚Äî dominate children‚Äôs diets. These products are stripped of their bran and germ, removing essential fiber, vitamins and minerals.

‚ÄúThe stripping of these components can lead to blood sugar spikes, increasing the risk of Type 2 diabetes,‚Äù the report states.¬†

The sugar situation is just as grim. Ultra-processed sugars can be found in 75% of packaged foods. The average American consumes 17 teaspoons of added sugar a day ‚Äî amounting to a whopping 60 pounds a year.

This sugar overload ‚Äî especially from high-fructose corn syrup and other additives ‚Äî may be playing a ‚Äúsignificant role‚Äù in the nation‚Äôs rise of childhood obesity, Type 2 diabetes and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, according to the report.

But it‚Äôs not just the ingredients ‚Äî it‚Äôs what industrial processing does to them.

The MAHA report warns that processing alters fiber content, caloric density and digestibility in ways that can hijack hunger hormones, short-circuit satiety signals and damage the gut microbiome.

‚ÄúIt shouldn‚Äôt be so hard to protect your family,‚Äù Ferrara said. ‚ÄúThey need to be more transparent with what‚Äôs in the food, but also how it‚Äôs processed.‚Äù¬†

Toxic situation

Astoria mom Carissa Serralta has always strived to feed her kids a healthy diet ‚Äî but it wasn‚Äôt until one of her newborn twin daughters was diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder, MCAD deficiency, that she saw just how flooded grocery stores are with ultra-processed junk.

The condition prevents her now 2-year-old, Mila, from properly metabolizing fats from seed oils like palm, coconut and avocado.

‚ÄúEighty to 90% of the brands you see on the shelf she can‚Äôt have,‚Äù Serralta told The Post. ‚ÄúIt could be anywhere from pasta to tortillas to Cheez-Its.‚Äù

That became a nightmare when she couldn‚Äôt produce enough breast milk ‚Äî and realized nearly all baby formulas on the market are loaded with seed oils.

‚ÄúThey say breast is best, but if you don‚Äôt have milk for your baby and you have no choice but to give them formula, and the formula has bad ingredients, what do you do?‚Äù she mused. ‚ÄúYour baby has to be fed.‚Äù

Doctors told Serralta to give Mila tiny doses of seed oils to build tolerance for formula ‚Äî but that led to months of relentless diarrhea.

The MAHA report notes that seed oils have flooded the US food supply, overtaking animal-based fats like butter and lard in American diets over the past century.

Finding safe foods has become ‚Äúa full-time job‚Äù for Serralta. Many of the items her daughter can eat aren‚Äôt available locally, forcing her to shop online or cook everything from scratch.

If Mila accidentally eats seed oil, it means an upset stomach, which Serralta said is painful but manageable. She is thankful it‚Äôs not something more severe like a peanut or gluten allergy.

The White House report highlights that childhood food allergies have soared 88% since 1997, while celiac disease in kids has jumped fivefold since the ‚Äô80s.

The diagnosis didn‚Äôt just change what Mila eats ‚Äî it transformed the rest of the family‚Äôs eating habits. Serralta shudders at the thought of her older son previously eating ultra-processed snacks.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost a scary thought, because I was so unaware of this before I had the twins,‚Äù she said.

And while she‚Äôs no fan of the current administration, Serralta said she welcomes any effort to expand access to healthier foods.

‚ÄúLess-processed foods have to be made available to all kids ‚Äî it shouldn‚Äôt just be online where people with lower incomes can‚Äôt access it,‚Äù she said.
item.author: McKenzie Beard

item.title: Êµ∑ÂÜõÁõ¥ÂçáÊú∫ÈôçËêΩÂú®Âç°Â§ö‰ΩêHSË∂≥ÁêÉÂú∫ÔºåÂèØÂÆπÁ∫≥300ÂêçÊÄ•ÂàáÁöÑÂ≠¶ÂëòÔºö ‚Äú‰ªñ‰ª¨‰∏∫Êàë‰ª¨Â∏¶Êù•‰∫ÜËà∞ÈòüÂë®‚Äù | Navy lands helicopter on Cardozo HS football field for 300 eager cadets: ‚ÄòThey brought Fleet Week to us‚Äô
item.description:
The Navy is all about higher education ‚Äî literally and figuratively.

The military branch landed an MH-60S Knighthawk chopper on the baseball field at Benjamin N. Cardozo High School¬†in Bayside on Friday in front of hundreds of bewildered and galvanized student cadets.

The demonstration ‚Äî a part of Fleet Week ‚Äî was a dream for the Queens high school‚Äôs Navy Junior Reserve Officers‚Äô Training Corps (NJROTC) four years in the making and marked the first time such an event had been done on city schools‚Äô property in at least a decade.

‚ÄúLast year, we went to Fleet Week. This year, they brought Fleet Week to us,‚Äù said Riddhi Chauhan, 16, a junior and next year‚Äôs cadet commanding officer.

The Post was afforded a bird‚Äôs eye view of the incredible ride, which kicked off at New Jersey‚Äôs Teterboro Airport, crossed over Central Park and through the length of Queens until coming to a spectacular rest at the high school.

Hundreds of students cheered on as the Naval officers from the Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) unit performed a fast rope demonstration ‚Äî meaning they slid down the tether onto the baseball field as the chopper hovered a few dozen feet off the ground.

The energy remained high throughout the remainder of the event as the high school cadets met with the officers and caught a glimpse of what their future might look like.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs huge. Just seeing everyone coming together for an event like this, it means the world to know that we‚Äôre all here for each other ‚Ä¶ We are one big family,‚Äù said Shanelle Kelly, 18, a senior looking forward to attending Norwich University, a military school in Vermont, in the fall.

Watching the helicopter demonstration and meeting the naval officers got Kelly ‚Äúso excited‚Äù to achieve her dreams of working with the Marine Warfare Unit, something she has chosen because she knows it will be challenging.

Cardozo had been vehemently vying for the helicopter and fast rope demonstration for four years ‚Äî almost as long as their NJROTC has been in existence.

The program boasts nearly 300 cadets ‚Äî roughly 23% of its total student population ‚Äî making it one of the fastest-growing in the country, according to Principal Meagan Colby, adding that not all of the cadets will go on to join the military, but most have aspirations of serving the country in some way.

For Chauhan ‚Äî the incoming program‚Äôs boss ‚Äî she only realized her dream of becoming a nuclear engineer for the Navy once she joined the NJROTC program last year.

She had joined the NJROTC because it looked like it offered a fun experience and would be a great resume builder, until it opened her eyes to what a career in the Navy could look like.

‚ÄúOnce you join it really changes your perspective. All of the branches are so unique and it‚Äôs so different of an experience from a 9-to-5 job,‚Äù she said.

Her predecessor, Bhaswi Singh, 17, is leaving to study pre-law at American University in the fall with future plans of joining the Navy after graduation.

‚ÄúI do want to have that moment in my career where I serve my country and give back,‚Äù the Bellerose native said, adding that she is in Cardozo‚Äôs law program.

‚ÄúToday is especially important to me. It gives respect and awareness about cadets do in the program, what a lot of our veterans do and how they serve the country, whether it be the Navy, Marines, Army ‚Ä¶ and there‚Äôs a helicopter, who doesn‚Äôt love that. And there‚Äôs music!‚Äù

For the servicemembers, the opportunity was just as valuable ‚Äî and offered some of them the chance to dispel some of the misconceptions that the Navy is purely tied to sea operations.

‚ÄúTheir feedback has been really rewarding ‚Äî to see how excited they are when we come in. I think we forget sometimes how important this is people? So it‚Äôs been a really good opportunity for me to be able to appreciate that,‚Äù said Erick Larson, one of the EOD servicemembers aboard the helicopter.

The division handles explosive threats and hazards, whether chemical, biological or nuclear and whether on land or underwater ‚Äî a heavily science-based unit that was especially intriguing to students at Cardozo, which boasts a variety of science programs.
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.title: ‰ΩøÁî®Âú£ËØûËÄÅ‰∫∫ÊúçË£ÖÁ≠ñÂàíÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇË¢≠ÂáªÂ∞ëÊï∞Ê∞ëÊóèÁöÑÊñ∞Á∫≥Á≤πÈÇ™ÊïôÈ¢ÜË¢ñË¢´ÊãñÂà∞ÁæéÂõΩÊé•ÂèóÂÆ°Âà§ | Neo-Nazi cult leader who plotted NYC attack on minorities using Santa costume hauled to US for trial
item.description:
The leader of the neo-Nazi ‚ÄúManiac Murder Cult,‚Äù who plotted to attack New York City on New Year‚Äôs Eve using a goon dressed as Santa Claus, was hauled to the US to face charges ‚Äî as the feds said his hateful screeds succeeded in radicalizing Americans into committing violence.

Georgian national Michail ‚ÄúCommander Butcher‚Äù Chkhikvishvili, 21, inspired ‚Äúmultiple senseless killings‚Äù around the world, including the deadly Antioch High School shooting in January ‚Äî where a radicalized ROTC cadet gunned down a 16-year-old teen girl in Nashville, according to a letter from the Justice Department Friday.

Prosecutors said that the Nashville shooter, 17-year-old Solomon Henderson, had proclaimed in audio recordings before the attack that he was ‚Äútaking action on behalf of MKY‚Äù and had explicitly mentioned Chkhikvishvili by name.

The feds also said that Chkhikvishvili was connected to a Turkey knife attack where a crazed Turkish teen wearing Nazi paraphernalia livestreamed himself stabbing five outside a mosque in August 2024.

Chkhikvishvili, who was arrested last year in Moldova, was extradited to the US on Thursday ‚Äî and pleaded not guilty at his arraignment Friday in Brooklyn Federal court on multiple felony counts, including solicitation of hate crime.

In a 22-page criminal complaint, prosecutors detailed Chkhikvishvili‚Äôs role as a leader and recruiter within the ‚ÄúManiac Murder Cult,‚Äù a Russia and Ukraine-based neo-Nazi group that promotes violence against racial minorities, Jewish people and other so-called ‚Äúundesirables.‚Äù

Chkhikvishvili, who lived with his grandmother in Brooklyn in 2022, published multiple editions of a manifesto called the ‚ÄúHater‚Äôs Handbook,‚Äù in which he encouraged others to commit school shootings and other mass terror attacks, while offering how-tos in order to pull off attacks, according to the indictment.

His manifesto shared by the alleged stabbed in Turkey, according to the filing ‚Äî which also pegs Chkhikvishvili to another livestream murder in Romania in April 2022.

Chkhikvishvili, who was arrested in Moldova last year, allegedly tried to plan a hate attack with one of his pal‚Äôs donning a Santa Clause costume who would hand out poison-laced candy to minorities across New York City.

The plot was foiled when the person he solicited for the attack was actually an undercover FBI agent.

He also planned a similar position candy stunt targeting Jewish school children in Brooklyn ‚Äî and sent information on how to make bombs and ricin-based poison using castor beans, according to court documents.

‚ÄúThe defendant has consistently demonstrated that he is capable of orchestrating deadly attacks from behind a computer screen at home,‚Äù the feds said in the filing. ‚ÄúMoreover, the defendant has repeatedly stated that he has committed acts of violence and that he intends to commit more. The Court should take the defendant at his word and detain him in the interest of public safety.‚Äù

Brooklyn Federal Magistrate Judge Peggy Kuo ordered Chkhikvishvili on the prosecution‚Äôs request finding that the mad man poses a danger to society and is considered a flight risk.

Chkhikvishvili‚Äôs attorney, Sam Gregory, and asked the judge for a psychological evaluation and to put the alleged neo-Nazi under suicide watch at the Metropolitan Detention Center.

The judge ordered Chkhikvishvili back to court for a status conference on June 11.
item.author: Kyle Schnitzer

item.title: ÊçÆÁß∞ÔºåÂä†ÂØÜÊäïËµÑËÄÖÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë±™ÂçéÂÖ¨ÂØìÊäòÁ£®‰∫ÜË¢´‰øòÁöÑÊÑèÂ§ßÂà©Ê∏∏ÂÆ¢Êï∞Âë®ÔºöÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê | Crypto investor allegedly tortured captive Italian tourist for weeks in luxe NYC apartment: sources
item.description:
A cryptocurrency investor from Kentucky was arrested Friday after an Italian tourist who had apparently been tied up and tortured inside a ritzy New York City apartment was able to escape, police sources said.

The victim, 28, broke out of the SoHo house of horrors Friday morning and immediately ran over to a police officer and told them he‚Äôd been held captive for more than two weeks, according to the sources.

John Woeltz, 37, was taken into custody and is expected to be charged with assault, the sources said.

Two other people believed to be employed by Woeltz, a crypto entrepreneur and investor, were waiting to be interviewed by police, sources said.

Woeltz and the victim apparently knew each other from previous business dealings, the sources said.

The tourist arrived in New York City from Italy on May 6 and went to the luxurious apartment ‚Äî but when he arrived, the suspect snatched his passport and tied him up, sources said.

After speaking with the victim, police searched the posh pad and discovered multiple torture items in plain sight.¬†

Officers also found polaroid photographs showing the victim being tied up and tortured as well as a gun, the sources said.

The department‚Äôs emergency service unit searched the premises to make sure their were no other torture victims, sources said.

The eight-bedroom apartment in one of the city‚Äôs most desirable neighborhoods rents for $30,000 to $40,000 per month.
item.author: Joe Marino, Patrick Reilly

item.title: ÈáéÁîüËßÜÈ¢ëÊòæÁ§∫ÔºåÊñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûË≠¶ÂØüÂú®ÁÅ´ËΩ¶Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ÊäπÂéª‰πãÂâçÂá†ÁßíÈíüÂ∞ÜÂèóÊçüÁöÑÂè∏Êú∫‰ªéËΩ¶‰∏äÊãâ‰∏ãÊù•ÔºåÂç°Âú®ËΩ®ÈÅì‰∏ä | Wild video shows NJ cops pull impaired driver from car stuck on tracks seconds before train obliterates it
item.description:
Two New Jersey cops rescued an impaired driver from a car stopped in the middle of train tracks just moments before it was hit, according to authorities and dramatic video.

Police officers Devin Hinchcliffe and John Ward arrived at a vehicle stopped on train tracks just after midnight last Monday, according to the Piscataway Township Police Department.

The driver, an unidentified man who was ‚Äúimpaired‚Äù and unable to exit their car, was dragged out by Hinchliffe and Ward as the crossing gates were coming down, dashcam footage provided by the department showed.

Mere seconds later, the high-speed train plowed down the tracks and hit the car, video provided by the department showed.

‚ÄúRecognizing the imminent danger posed by an approaching train, the officers swiftly and safely removed the driver just seconds before impact,‚Äù the department wrote in the statement

‚ÄúTheir quick action prevented a potential tragedy, and we commend Officer Hinchcliffe and Officer Ward for their prompt and effective response.‚Äù

It is not yet known if the driver, whose name has not been released, will face charges, according to WPVI.
item.author: Zoe Hussain

item.title: ÂΩ≠ÂçöÁ§æÁõüÂèãÊîØÊåÅCuomoÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÈïøÁ´ûÈÄâ‚ÄîÂâçÊîøÂ∫úÂÆ£Â∏É390‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÁöÑÁ´ûÈÄâÁ≠πÊ¨æ | Bloomberg allies throw support behind Cuomo‚Äôs NYC mayoral bid ‚Äî as ex-gov announces $3.9M campaign fundraising haul
item.description:
Well-heeled allies of former Mayor Michael Bloomberg are throwing their weight ‚Äî and their deep pocketbooks ‚Äî behind Andrew Cuomo in New York City‚Äôs mayoral race, The Post has learned.

Cuomo‚Äôs campaign announced Friday that it raised a record $3.9 million ‚Äî and a top source revealed the donors include the former mayor‚Äôs daughter Emma Bloomberg, who gave the $2,100 maximum contribution to the ex-governor‚Äôs political comeback bid.

Bloomberg‚Äôs right hand Kevin Sheekey, who ran the billionaire‚Äôs 2020 presidential bid and is a top exec at his namesake media company, also donated to the Cuomo campaign‚Äôs kitty, the source said.

Thomas Secunda ‚Äî the billionaire co-founder of Bloomberg LP ‚Äî gave $40,000 to the pro-Cuomo super PAC Fix the City, according to the source.

‚ÄúThe donations show warmth from the Bloomberg orbit and Mike,‚Äù the source said.

With anticipated public matching funds, Cuomo will have raised roughly $8.28 million since announcing his campaign on Feb. 28.

The donations illustrate the growing sense of inevitability swirling around Cuomo‚Äôs mayoral run, as well as Bloomberg‚Äôs likely misgivings about Israel-bashing state Assemblyman Zohran Mamdani, who has solidified a strong second-place standing in the Democratic primary race.

Mamdani has been a vocal critic of Israel, to the point many Jewish activists consider antisemitic.

The billionaire Bloomberg, by contrast, is a big backer of Israel.

He recently donated $44 million to Israel‚Äôs nonprofit medical service and this week visited the Charlotte R. Bloomberg Mother and Child Center, named after his mother, in Jerusalem.

Cuomo holds a massive lead in the Democratic mayoral primary of 37%, with the Democratic socialist Mamdani behind with 18%, according to a recent poll.

But Mamdani led among voters under age 45 ‚Äî with 38% compared to 18% for Cuomo, according to the survey by the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion.

The donations to Cuomo are also arguably a blow to Mayor Eric Adams, who is running as an independent as his political fortunes fell amid his now-dismissed federal corruption probe.

Bloomberg, aside from some personal meetings with Adams, has largely steered clear of New York politics.

The former mayor‚Äôs financial network of loyalists is deep and wide, so it‚Äôs likely other contributions will flow to Cuomo.
item.author: Carl Campanile, Matt Troutman

item.title: Âì•‰º¶ÊØî‰∫öÂπøÊí≠ÂÖ¨Âè∏Âú®Âêë‚ÄúÂî§ÈÜíÊö¥Âæí‚ÄùÂ±àÊúçÂêéÂêëË¢´Ëß£ÈõáÁöÑÈ´òÁÆ°ÊîØ‰ªòËøë1000‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÔºöËØâËÆº | CBS to pay sacked exec nearly $10 million after caving to ‚Äòwoke mob‚Äô: suit
item.description:
CBS must pay nearly $10 million to an executive accused of racist, sexist comments after caving to ‚Äúwoke mob‚Äù and firing him before investigation into his conduct was complete, according to an arbitration appeals panel and his attorney.

The appeal panel confirmed last week that CBS made a multi-million dollar mistake when they tried to rewrite the terms of termination months after sacking former president of CBS Television Stations Peter Dunn, which would have stripped him of back pay and stock payouts.¬†

‚ÄúThis was never about Peter‚Äôs conduct ‚Äî it was to appease the woke mob,‚Äù his lawyer Larry Hutcher told The Post. ‚ÄúIt was like the red scare, and it was very short sighted and unfair.‚Äù

A CBS spokesperson told The Post that a ‚Äúprocedural issue‚Äù led to the arbitration ruling in his favor, and that they ‚Äústrongly disagree‚Äù with the decision.

‚ÄúFour¬†years ago, we removed Peter Dunn as head of the CBS Television Stations for reasons that have been well documented and reported publicly,‚Äù the spokesperson said. ‚ÄúThis decision was not based on the substance of¬†the allegations against Mr. Dunn.‚Äù

The media company has had numerous shake-ups and high-profile departures recently as they try to appease Trump officials who need to sign off on a merger proposal.

The Dunn drama began in 2021, when an article by the Los Angeles Times accused the longtime executive of fostering a hostile work environment.

One former employee claimed Dunn had made ‚Äúracist, sexist, homophobic and discriminatory comments,‚Äù including calling a black evening anchor at a local affiliate in Philadelphia ‚Äúa jive guy.‚Äù

A former news director also claimed Dunn called another anchor ‚Äútoo gay.‚Äù

CBS immediately suspended Dunn, who worked at the network for 20 years, and another executive named in the report, and began an internal investigation.

But then CBS fired Dunn before the they finished the investigation, but did not list the reason for the sacking as ‚Äúfor-cause‚Äù at the time, according to court documents.

Rather, CBS cited the ongoing investigation in its termination letter to Dunn, and said he would continue to be paid ‚Äúas though your termination is without cause,‚Äù and they could alter the termination terms once the investigation ended, according to court filings.¬†

When the investigation completed four months later, CBS said they were converting Dunn‚Äôs termination to ‚Äúfor cause,‚Äù which would strip him of millions in payouts owed in back pay and equity.

Hutcher, however, said that the networks decision to first fire Dunn in the face of the ‚Äúwoke‚Äù blowback and then to retroactively decide that the firing was ‚Äúfor cause‚Äù after their probe was a huge mistake.

‚ÄúThe proper and prudent response would have been to suspend him, continue to pay him, wait for the investigation to be completed, and then fire him,‚Äù Hutcher said.

When Dunn took CBS‚Äôs move to arbitration, a panel of retired judges said the network clearly violated his employment contract, which stated that CBS had to determine at the time of his firing if it were ‚Äúfor cause‚Äù or ‚Äúwithout cause.‚Äù

The contract did not allow for ‚Äúa new and nebulous third option‚Äù which would grant ‚ÄúCBS the (apparently unfettered) discretion to defer the ‚Äòcause‚Äô determination,‚Äù a judge wrote last year, ruling in favor of Dunn.

CBS appealed the decision, and another set of retired judges unanimously confirmed the ruling last week, ordering CBS to pay Dunn over $7 million, plus interest, for a total of $9.78 million.

‚ÄúThe Parties could have drafted such a provision,‚Äù the appeal panel ruled, ‚Äúbut did not.‚Äù

Hutcher said that in 50 years of practicing law, it was ‚Äúthe first time I ever had an appeal in an arbitration,‚Äù but said he was pleased with the outcome.

‚ÄúThis case was always about Peter Dunn trying to restore his otherwise impeccable reputation that he spent over 20 years at CBS developing,‚Äù Hutcher said.¬†

‚ÄúWe are grateful that the original arbitrator and that the appeals panel agreed with Mr. Dunn that he had been wrongfully terminated, and that we look forward to the award being confirmed in the Supreme Court so that we can enforce this judgment.‚Äù

A CBS spokesperson said ‚Äúwe stand¬†by the findings of our third-party investigation and the decision made to terminate Mr. Dunn for cause. We‚Äôre grateful for the many voices who spoke up in a process that led to significant cultural change at our television stations.‚Äù
item.author: Peter Senzamici

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂú®ÂºÄÊîæÊµ∑Êª©ÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂ§©ÂÆ£Â∏ÉÂ§èÂ≠£ÂÆâÂÖ®ËÆ°Âàí | NYC announces summer safety plan on first day of open beaches
item.description:
The beach is back!

NYC beaches are officially open for the summer, and Mayor Adams laid out a plan Friday to ensure New Yorkers stay safe while enjoying the rivieras of the Big Apple.

The safety strategy will seek to ensure that locals are protected ‚Äúvia air, land, and sea‚Äù in a multi-agency effort.

‚ÄúThe official summer season in the city starts today and as we stay in the Bronx, we‚Äôre outside,‚Äù said Mayor Adams at Orchard beach in The Bronx Friday morning.

‚ÄúWe want all New Yorkers to enjoy the summer in the greatest city in the world, and we have so many activities that are happening, but we must do it in a safe way,‚Äù he said.

The framework covers crime, heat and fire safety, water and beach safety, street safety, and youth and community programs.

The NYPD will be launching its 2025 summer crime reduction plan, which will add more than 1,500 officers to posts in 70 summer deployment zones. The police department also added a ‚Äòquality of life division‚Äô which will enforce noise complaints, illegal mopeds, and other concerns that tend to ramp up over the warmer months.

‚ÄúOn land, in the air, or by sea, the men and women of the New York City Police Department will be keeping New Yorkers safe this summer,‚Äù said NYPD Commissioner Jessica Tisch Friday.

The emergency management division is also launching a ‚ÄòBeat the Heat campaign‚Äô which shares preventative measures in extreme heat ‚Äî in which more than 500 New Yorkers die each year. The city has designated ‚Äòcooling centers‚Äô that can be found on a map on the city‚Äôs website.

At city beaches, lifeguards will be on duty daily from 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM ‚Äî and swimming is prohibited outside of those hours. Lifeguards will also be manning public outdoor pools, which open for the season Friday, June 27, daily between 11:00 AM and 3:00 PM and 4:00 PM and 7:00¬†PM.¬†¬†

Beach goers may also notice drones flying overhead this summer. The tech will be monitoring shark activity and can even throw flotation devices to swimmers in danger.

‚ÄúAlthough the weather tells a different story, the summer season is underway, and the FDNY is ready for it,‚Äù said FDNY Commissioner Robert Tucker, as cloudy, rainy weather dipped into the low 50s Friday..

‚ÄúIn coordination with our agency partners, the FDNY is prepared to patrol our beaches on land and over water, with our beach Gators and our drones. We know the warm weather brings many opportunities for enjoying the outdoors and the water, and our members will be there to make sure that help is available for New Yorkers who need it.‚Äù
item.author: Khristina Narizhnaya, Hannah Fierick

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂ∏ÇÈïøÂÄôÈÄâ‰∫∫Zohran MamdaniÂä†ÂÄçÊîØÊåÅBDS ‚Äî‰∏ç‰ºöËØ¥‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÊúâÊùÉ‰Ωú‰∏∫ÁäπÂ§™ÂõΩÂÆ∂Â≠òÂú® | NYC mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani doubles down on BDS support ‚Äî won‚Äôt say Israel has right to exist as Jewish state
item.description:
Democratic socialist mayoral hopeful Zohran Mamdani doubled down on his support for the Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions movement against Israel ‚Äî and refused to say the country has a right to exist as a Jewish state.

Mamdani stayed firm in his support for the Palestinian-led BDS effort, calling it a ‚Äúlegitimate movement,‚Äù during a Q&A with Democratic primary candidates hosted by the UJA-Federation of New York on Thursday evening.

‚ÄúMy support for BDS is consistent with my core of my politics, which is non-violence,‚Äù the Queens assemblyman said when pressed by Jewish Insider‚Äôs editor-in-chief, Josh Kraushaar.

‚ÄúI think that it is a legitimate movement when you are seeking to find compliance with international law,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúThe effectiveness of tactics of boycott, divestment and sanctions in order to motivate that compliance at the state level, on an individual level and that‚Äôs where my support for it comes from.‚Äù

The state assemblyman from Queens said he believes Israel has a right to exist. But when pushed on whether it should exist as a Jewish state, he carefully sidestepped.

‚ÄúI believe Israel has a right to exist, and it has a right to exist also with equal rights for all,‚Äù he said.

Mamdani ‚Äî a lefty Democratic Socialists of America-backed politician ‚Äî was peppered with questions about his stance on Israel during the event from the UJA-Federation, a massive philanthropic group supporting the Jewish community.

The forum came just days after The Post unearthed a social media clip of the pro-Palestinian assemblyman leading a ‚ÄúBDS‚Äù chant during a May 11, 2021, anti-Israel protest.

Despite Mamdani‚Äôs open criticism of Israel, the lawmaker received a fairly warm welcome from those in attendance, according to recordings obtained by The Post, which, along with other press, was barred from entry at the door.

Those inside the event ‚Äî which took place some 24 hours after a pro-Palestinian radical gunned down two innocent Israeli Embassy staff members in Washington, DC ‚Äî described the security as ‚Äúwild,‚Äù as organizers revoked the tickets of several people.

During his roughly 20-minute appearance, moderators asked Mamdani about his remarks that if elected mayor, he would order the NYPD to arrest Benjamin Netanyahu if the Israeli prime minister ever set foot in the Big Apple.

‚ÄúUltimately, my position is one that I believe our city should be in compliance with international law,‚Äù Mamdani said, noting the International Criminal Court has issued a warrant for the Israeli leader, adding that he‚Äôd have the same answer if he was asked the question about Russian President Vladimir Putin.

‚ÄúWhat troubles me greatly is that Benjamin Netanyahu has also issued military commands from this very city when visiting it,‚Äù he said.

Mamdani campaign spokesman Andrew Epstein said the candidate has been ‚Äúconsistent‚Äù in his beliefs regarding Israel.

‚ÄúZohran has been consistent in his belief that Israel has the right to exist, a responsibility to adhere to international law, and that he supports non-violent movements to ensure compliance with that law,‚Äù Epstein said in a statement Friday.

‚ÄúHe was heartened by the warm reception last night to his vision for a New York that‚Äôs safe and affordable for everyone.‚Äù

Mamdani, who has repeatedly come up second in the polls vying for the Democratic nomination, behind ex-Gov. Andrew Cuomo, has recently been dogged by his anti-Israel rhetoric.

He faced blowback from the Jewish community for failing to sign onto a¬†pair of resolutions recognizing Israel and the Holocaust ‚Äî in what his campaign wrote off as a procedural error.

The revelation came just days after he got the endorsement of anti-Israel ex-‚ÄúSquad‚Äù member Rep. Jamaal Bowman in the race for mayor of New York City, which is home to the largest population of Jews outside Israel.

The lawmaker also pushed the ‚ÄúNot On Our Dime Act,‚Äù which would have stopped New York nonprofits from supporting any groups that are involved with West Bank settlements.
item.author: Craig McCarthy, Carl Campanile

item.title: Êñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÈÖíÂêßÂõ†ÊëáÊªö‰πêÈòüÂèçÁâπÊúóÊôÆÁöÑËØÑËÆ∫ËÄåÂèñÊ∂à‰∫ÜÊñØÊôÆÊûóÊñØÊ±ÄÁöÑÂ∞ÅÈù¢‰πêÈòüÔºö ‚Äú‰∏ç‰ºöÊîØÊåÅ‰ªñÁöÑÂÖ¨Áâõ-t‚Äù | NJ bar cancels Springsteen cover band over rocker‚Äôs anti-Trump comments: ‚ÄòWon‚Äôt stand for his bulls‚Äìt‚Äô
item.description:
Bruce Springsteen just got cancelled ‚Äî at the Jersey Shore.

A tribute band dedicated to The Boss‚Äô music pulled the plug on a gig at a bar not far from his Garden State home after a dispute with its owner over the singer-songwriter‚Äôs anti-Trump comments, according to a report.

No Surrender, a 20-year-old nine-piece Springsteen cover band from New Jersey, was slated to play Riv‚Äôs Toms River Hub on May 30th ‚Äî until the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on Fire‚Äù singer kicked off his European tour packed with on-stage rants flaming President Trump, NJ Advance Media reported.

Band leader Brad Hobicorn¬†started receiving ‚Äúconcerned texts‚Äù from bar owner Tony Rivoli shortly after Springsteen‚Äôs comments went viral, according to the outlet.

By Sunday, Rivoli allegedly pulled the plug on the show that was booked 9 months in advance. He texted Hobicorn that the gig would be ‚Äútoo risky at the moment,‚Äù citing the restaurant‚Äôs conservative customer base, the outlet reported.

‚ÄúUnfortunately it‚Äôs just too much money I wanted to do the Springsteen tribute for that money in my social media team would have promoted it we would have done well but now because Bruce can‚Äôt keep his mouth shut we‚Äôre screwed,‚Äù Rivoli wrote in a text message to Hobicorn obtained by NJ Advance Media.

Hobicorn offered to have his band play only classic-rock covers instead of Springsteen, but Rivoli balked at paying $2,500 for a classic-rock cover band, the outlet said.

In a message sent to the band‚Äôs bassist, Guy Fleming, Rivoli wrote, ‚ÄúWhenever the national anthem plays, my bar stands and is in total silence, that‚Äôs our clientele. Toms River is red and won‚Äôt stand for his bull‚Äî.‚Äù

After Fleming posted about the situation on Facebook, Rivoli seemed to change his tune a bit ‚Äî insisting he never cancelled the gig and had changed his mind. But the band decided it was too late for the bar owner to backtrack.

‚ÄúThis is not political for us at all,‚Äù Hobicorn told the outlet Thursday. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just a cover band that‚Äôs trying to make some money and people rely on it financially. We‚Äôre the ones really getting hurt.‚Äù

‚ÄúAt that point, there were negative vibes about the whole thing,‚Äù Hobicorn said. ‚ÄúThere was definitely a safety concern,‚Äù he said.

Rivoli, though, insisted the cover band could have played.

‚ÄúAs of (Wednesday), they could have played as No Surrender,‚Äù Rivoli told the outlet.

‚ÄúI think a lot of people of my base would not have came, but I could have been wrong. You know, who knows? You can‚Äôt predict what people are going to do.‚Äù

Toms River bar and restaurant joints have previously sparked backlash for their conservative slant.

Aqua Blu Kitchen & Cocktails in Toms River put a hamburger on its menu dedicated to the right wing extremist group the ‚ÄúProud Boys‚Äù in January ‚Äî leading to a massive online backlash and an apology from the owner.

Springsteen ‚Äî who was born in Long Branch and raised in¬†Freehold¬†‚Äî¬†lambasted Trump‚Äôs administration as ‚Äúcorrupt, incompetent and treasonous‚Äù¬†while kicking off the European leg of his ‚ÄúLand of Hope and Dreams‚Äù tour in Manchester, England last week.

Last Friday, Trump slammed the musician, calling him ‚ÄúHighly Overrated‚Äù and ‚Äúdumb as a rock‚Äù for going ‚Äúto a Foreign Country to speak badly about the President of the United States.‚Äù

‚ÄúNever liked him, never liked his music, or his Radical Left Politics and, importantly, he‚Äôs not a talented guy ‚Äî Just a pushy, obnoxious JERK, who fervently supported Crooked Joe Biden, a mentally incompetent FOOL, and our WORST EVER President, who came close to destroying our Country,‚Äù he posted to Truth Social.

Instead of playing The Riv‚Äôs Tom‚Äôs River Hub, No Surrender will instead play Headliner Oasis in Neptune Township on May 30, according to the outlet.
item.author: Zoe Hussain

item.title: Âè∏Ê≥ïÈÉ®Â∞±Â∫áÊä§ÊîøÁ≠ñËµ∑ËØâÊñ∞Ê≥ΩË•øÂ∑ûÁöÑÂè¶Â§ñ‰∏â‰∏™ÂüéÂ∏ÇÁ∫ΩÁì¶ÂÖãÔºö ‚ÄúÊ≠£Èù¢ÊîªÂáª‚Äù | DOJ sues Newark, three more New Jersey cities over sanctuary policies: ‚ÄòA frontal assault‚Äô
item.description:
‚ÄòWASHINGTON ‚Äî The Department of Justice sued four New Jersey cities Thursday for allegedly obstructing federal immigration authorities with their sanctuary policies, The Post can exclusively reveal.

The lawsuit claims officials in Newark, Jersey City, Paterson and Hoboken have been unconstitutionally blocking the feds from coordinating with local authorities to apprehend and deport illegal immigrants.

Acting Assistant Attorney General Yaakov Roth wrote in the complaint that the local policies amounted to ‚Äúa frontal assault on the federal immigration laws and the federal authorities that administer them.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe express purpose and clear effect of these policies ‚Ä¶ is to thwart federal immigration enforcement,‚Äù Roth said. ‚Äú[E]ven where local law enforcement wants to help the United States deal with the nation‚Äôs immigration crisis, the Challenged Policies impede them from doing so.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis not only puts the safety of officers at risk, but also endangers the broader communities they are sworn to protect,‚Äù he added, claiming the policies violate the US Constitution‚Äôs supremacy clause.

The suit comes on the heels of a high-profile clash May 9 involving Democratic politicians and federal officials at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detention center in Newark, which ended in the arrest of the city‚Äôs mayor, Ras Baraka, and led to federal charges against Rep. LaMonica McIver (D-NJ).

‚ÄúRecent events have proven that these New Jersey officials care more about political showmanship than the safety of their communities,‚Äù US Attorney General Pam Bondi said in a statement.

‚ÄúAs I have made clear, this Justice Department does not tolerate local officials in sanctuary cities obstructing immigration enforcement: there is more litigation to come.‚Äù

The DOJ has filed similar lawsuits earlier this year challenging the sanctuary policies of New York, Illinois and Colorado.

The Post has reached out to reps of each city for comment.
item.author: Josh Christenson, Jennie Taer

item.title: ‰º†ÂçïÊï¶‰øÉÊïôÂ∏à‰ªé‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÂâ•Á¶ªÂú®Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â≠¶Ê†°ÈùûÊ≥ïÂàÜÈÖçÁöÑÂÖªËÄÅÂü∫ÈáëÔºö ‚ÄúËøùÂèç‰ø°‰ªª‚Äù | Flyer urging teachers to divest pension funds from Israel illegally distributed in NYC schools: ‚ÄòViolated trust‚Äô
item.description:
A controversial antisemitic flyer urging teachers voting in union elections to back a campaign to divest pension funds from Israel was improperly distributed in some New York City public schools, The Post has learned.

The incendiary petition circulated as two Israeli Embassy staffers were killed by a suspected terrorist in Washington, DC, on Wednesday night.

‚ÄúThis UFT election season, vote for candidates who divest our pension from genocide,‚Äù the flyer said.

‚ÄúSign the petition to show UFT candidates that you will be voting with divestment in mind during the election.‚Äù

Jewish civil rights groups such as the Anti-Defamation League said the economic boycott, divestment and sanctions movement is antisemitic because it seeks to undermine and destroy the world‚Äôs only Jewish state.

Pro-Israel teachers said the handout had been distributed to at least three Manhattan schools: two in the same building on West 17th Street, the New York City Lab for Collaborative Studies Middle School and the Museum HS, as well as the Mosaic Preparatory Academy elementary school on East 111th Street, and at least one in the Bronx.

Outraged teachers said the flyer has been handed out in schools by teachers claiming to be UFT officers, or who were not from their schools.

‚ÄúI was definitely shocked. It violated the trust in the building. It came from a teacher from another school,‚Äù a staffer at the 17th Street building said.

‚ÄúThese are blood libels. They don‚Äôt belong in the education space.‚Äù

Another teacher who requested anonymity said, ‚ÄúAs a Jewish educator, I was deeply troubled when receiving this letter with clear antisemitic undertones ‚Äî especially in the wake of the tragic killing of two civilians targeted for being Jewish.

‚ÄúThis act of hate is unacceptable. Our schools and communities must remain places of inclusion and respect for all.‚Äù

Karen Feldman, co-founder of the New York City Public School Alliance, blasted the use of ‚Äúschool channels to distribute political and antisemitic propaganda, especially during a union election.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe materials were filled with false claims of genocide and hate-filled rhetoric that incites violence ‚Äî just like the horrific murder of two Israeli Americans in DC just last night.‚Äù

The UFT said distribution of politically charged flyers violated its rules for electioneering for its internal elections of officers.

Candidates running for union positions are allowed to distribute campaign material about the slate they‚Äôre running on ‚Äî but not about other political issues.

‚ÄúThe flyer is a political document. No one should be handing out political materials under the guise that it is campaign material in the union‚Äôs internal election. It is not,‚Äù a spokesperson for the UFT and president Mike Mulgrew said.

A rep for city Schools Chancellor Melissa Aviles-Ramos said the flyers are being removed from schools.

‚ÄúNew York City Public Schools has the right and responsibility to prohibit the distribution of materials that can be perceived as disruptive and offensive to staff and students. These flyers, which were not created by New York City Public Schools, are clearly disruptive, and we are taking appropriate action to remove them,‚Äù a Department of Education spokesperson said.

The anti-Israel advocates said the New York City Teacher Retirement has $135 million of pension funds invested in Israeli holdings.

The flyer said the Israeli military has slaughtered tens of thousands of civilians and children since Oct. 7, 2023, citing the anti-Israel Al-Jazeera media outlet as a source.

It conveniently omits mentioning that was the date when Hamas‚Äô precipitated the war in Gaza by invading Israel, killing 1,200 people and taking scores of hostages ‚Äî some of whom still have not been released.

It‚Äôs just the latest controversy regarding Israel-bashing literature spreading in schools.

Last month, a Department of Education newsletter claiming Israel is committing ‚Äúgenocide in Gaza‚Äù was sent out to hundreds of teachers ‚Äî prompting fuming Jewish educators to call it out as another example of ingrained antisemitism in the city‚Äôs public school system.

In response, Chancellor Aviles-Ramos suspended release of mass communications sent to educators, students and parents without her approval.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶È™ëËá™Ë°åËΩ¶ÁöÑ‰∫∫ËØïÂõæÊãØÊïë‰∏ÄÊù°ÊúâÊØíÁöÑËõá‚ÄîÁªìÊûúÂèó‰∫ÜÂèØÊÄïÁöÑ‰º§ | NYC cyclist tried to save a venomous snake ‚Äî and ended up with a gruesome injury
item.description:
A New York cyclist who tried to save a venomous snake from being run over was instead bitten by it ‚Äî¬†sending him to the hospital with a grotesquely swollen purple finger.

Dan Geiger, a writer from Manhattan, was pedaling along New Jersey‚Äôs Palisades Cliffs when he spotted the copperhead snake lying across the pavement and feared it would be run over by a car, according to Hackensack Memorial Health.

‚ÄúI nudged it,‚Äù Geiger told Fox 5 of the viper snake that seemed ‚Äúlethargic‚Äù and didn‚Äôt move.

‚ÄúI just sort of nudged again, and I was just too close,‚Äù he recalled.

‚ÄúMy hand was just too close to its head, I guess, and it just struck me with precision and speed.‚Äù

Two good Samaritans helped Geiger call 911, and he was rushed to Hackensack University Medical Center, where a specially trained toxicology team treated his bite, the hospital said.

Geiger‚Äôs finger had ballooned and turned a dark shade of purple, gnarly photos show.

After assessing the bite, doctors administered antivenom to stop permanent damage to the unlucky cyclist‚Äôs hand.

‚ÄúOnce you get antivenom, I think people expect that it‚Äôs like this miracle cure where all of a sudden like everything goes back to normal,‚Äù Dr. Daria Falkowitz, director of the Division of Medical Toxicology at Hackensack University Medical Center, told Fox 5.

‚ÄúIt just stops things from getting worse, and so whatever tissue damage has already occurred prior to receiving it, is there. Though initially it doesn‚Äôt look bad, the damage has been done, so we expect some progression over a day or two.‚Äù

Geiger spent two nights at¬†the hospital for observation and was discharged, though he still won‚Äôt be able to use his hand for a week, the hospital said.

Though bites are fairly rare, venomous snakes inhabit the surrounding area of Bergen County.

‚ÄúThey most of the time avoid people,‚Äù Dr. Falkowitz told the outlet.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more of a risk for like little kids and pets that you want to try and keep out of there and try not to specifically reach for them.‚Äù
item.author: Zoe Hussain

item.title: ÈöèÁùÄ‰ª§‰∫∫‰∏çÂÆâÁöÑÊñ∞ÁªÜËäÇÁöÑÂá∫Áé∞ÔºåÂº∫Â•∏ÁäØÂõ†ÈáéËõÆÂú∞ÊÆ¥ÊâìÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â¶àÂ¶àËÄåË¢´ÂÅáÈáä | Rapist out on parole nabbed for savagely beating NYC mom unconscious as disturbing new details emerge
item.description:
A convicted rapist was in custody Friday for savagely beating unconscious a mom on Randall‚Äôs island ‚Äî having called 911 to report the attack himself, according to police sources.

The suspect was out on parole for rape and was wearing his ankle monitor during the vicious assault, police sources said.

He had been living at a shelter on Randall‚Äôs Island when he allegedly bludgeoned the 44-year-old mom, now identified as Diana Agudelo, as she was walking along the bikepath at 600 E. 125th St. around 11:30 p.m. Friday, cops and sources said.

The suspect reported the beating to 911 and fled, sources said.

Agudelo suffered facial fractures ‚Äî including a cracked skull and a broken nose ‚Äî in what NYPD Chief Joseph Kenny called ‚Äúone of the worst beatings I‚Äôve ever seen.‚Äù

The mother was rushed to Elmhurst Hospital unresponsive in critical condition.

The suspect was convicted of rape and sentenced to 12 years in prison in 2013 in the Bronx, according to jail records.
item.author: Joe Marino, Patrick Reilly

item.title: Miracle on IceÁöÑKen MorrowÂ∞ÜÊ∞∏ËøúÂú®Ë∑ØÊòìÊñØÂÆâÈÇ£Â∑ûËØ∫ÊñØÊ≥¢ÁâπÊã•ÊúâÁ¨¨‰∫å‰∏™ÂÆ∂ | Miracle on Ice‚Äôs Ken Morrow will¬†always have second home in Northport, LI
item.description:
One day, Islanders great and Miracle on Ice member Ken Morrow was going for a leisurely drive in Huntington Village when a pair of police officers suddenly pulled him over.

‚ÄúWhen they came up, I didn‚Äôt know why. I didn‚Äôt think I‚Äôd been speeding or anything,‚Äù Morrow told The Post.

‚ÄúAnd their first words to me were, ‚ÄòI thought¬†that was the Stanley Cup in the back of your car.‚Äô With their lights going, they stood at my back window looking at the Stanley Cup and reading the names.‚Äù

It became one of the many memorable moments for longtime Northport resident Morrow, who won Lord Stanley‚Äôs hardware four straight times with the Isles ‚Äî the first coming mere months after defeating the USSR juggernaut in Lake Placid.

In the¬†Michigan native‚Äôs words, it didn‚Äôt take long to become a bona fide everyday Long Islander.

‚ÄúYou were just part of the local community, and you didn‚Äôt get mobbed or anything like that,‚Äù said Morrow, who now calls Kansas City home as director of pro scouting in the Islanders organization.

Still, the defenseman who fell in love with local beaches and drives on the scenic North Shore would ‚Äúget a couple of people that would come up and knock on the door‚Äù occasionally.

‚ÄúI remember one time, we had a school bus driver pull in our driveway, and we were trying to figure out what the heck was going on until he came up to the door,‚Äù he recalled.

‚ÄúI struck up a lot of conversations with people. It certainly didn‚Äôt bother me at all that people wanted to do that.‚Äù

Now, nearly 45 years to that fateful day of May 24, 1980, when Morrow and the team celebrated their first Cup win in overtime of Game 6 against the Flyers, he remembers it all like it was yesterday.

‚ÄúWhen Bobby Nystrom scored, I think the feeling was relief as much as it was joy,‚Äù Morrow said, adding that even climbing stairs became challenging when the Stanley Cup Final rolled around.

The Olympic gold medalist, now 68, returned to the island two summers ago and recounted his days on top of the world in his memoir, ‚ÄúKen Morrow: Miracle Gold, Four Stanley Cups, and a Lifetime of Islanders Hockey,‚Äù co-written by sportswriter Allan Kreda.

From gold to silver

It was a blur when he arrived in Nassau County just weeks after the greatest hockey game ever played.

Morrow and his family first stayed in a Holiday Inn on Old Country Road near the beloved Nassau Coliseum, but they didn‚Äôt catch much of an authentic glimpse of the island he adores at first.

What he did see, however, were fans salivating for their first chance to win it all in the spring of 1980.

‚ÄúYou had a lot of interactions with the fans, which was a really great thing.‚Äù

His playing days were when spectators were much more accessible, as players parked outside the arena ‚Äî right by pregame festivities that Morrow distinctly holds dear.

‚ÄúThe tailgating is something I‚Äôll always remember ‚Äî probably unique to Long Island. The people were out there tailgating hours before games,‚Äù he said, adding it was the first time he ever saw the grills going for hockey games and fans escorting players toward the door.

Leaving after a victory, when cars would blare a honk to the tune of ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs go Islanders!‚Äù is also something Morrow cherishes deep down.

‚ÄúI probably did it, too, at some point,‚Äù No. 6 said with a laugh.

Rocking the barn

The real magic, however, came inside the Uniondale walls that shook with the passion of thousands who showed up every spring to watch their Isles vie for another title in the early 1980s.

‚ÄúThe roar,‚Äù Morrow, who still gets standing ovations at games, recalled, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs a memory that will stay with me. You could hear it through the walls of the locker room. It just gave you chills to walk out.‚Äù

Rather than looking back at the glory days that well predate state-of-the-art UBS Arena, he‚Äôs enthusiastic about what the team has done since ‚Äî especially when the old barn rocked at dynasty-level decibels.

Morrow distinctly recalls the shaking that followed the Shawn Bates penalty shot of 2002 and the Isles‚Äô conference final run nearly two decades later in 2021.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something about the old barn, and there have been some great moments in the history of the New York Islanders ‚Äî especially in the playoffs,‚Äù Morrow said.

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt take much to bring that out in our fans today.‚Äù
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: ÈïøÂ≤õÂûíÁêÉÈòü‰∫´ÂèóÂéÜÂè≤ËµõÂ≠£ÔºåÊé•‰∏ãÊù•ÊòØÂ≠£ÂêéËµõ | Long Island softball team enjoying historic season with playoffs next
item.description:
Sachem North softball is reveling in a first-time milestone as the team boasted its best league record with a 15-4 season.

‚ÄúYou kind of don‚Äôt realize what you‚Äôre in until it‚Äôs over,‚Äù manager Ken Sasso told The Post. ‚ÄúBut when we won that 15th game, and I looked back at our record, I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòWow, we never won 15 games in-league.‚Äô ‚Äù

Sophomore catcher Delaney Mathes is hitting an unfathomable .685 heading into a playoff matchup with Half Hollow Hills on Friday.

Mathes isn‚Äôt thinking about personal accolades, though ‚Äî especially after a second-round exit against Sachem East last season.

‚ÄúI definitely want to win the county ‚Ä¶ especially just to make it farther than last year would be really great,‚Äù she said.

The team wants to follow suit with the high-octane energy it‚Äôs known for.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs never a down moment,‚Äù third baseman Brooke Giordano said, with junior pitcher Dani Brennan (left) adding that things reach a fever pitch when the bats are hot.

‚ÄúEveryone is always on the fence and we‚Äôre always cheering,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what makes us different from the other teams, because I don‚Äôt think they cheer as well as we do.‚Äù

Sachem balances spirit with composure as coaches focus ‚Äúmore on the mental part over mechanics,‚Äù said junior shortstop Bella Kriklava, who is thrilled to try to win it all.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre helping us stay in the right state of mind.‚Äù

The Class B softball title series starts with the top seed, Carle Place (16-5), taking on the third seed, East Rockaway (14-4), at Farmingdale State College at 10:30 a.m. Saturday and Sunday.

In baseball, No. 1 seed Wantagh (19-3) travels to No. 2 seed Wheatley (18-3-1) for Game 2 of the semifinals Friday at 4:30 p.m.
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: ÊÄÄÂ≠ïÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Êñ∞Èóª‰∏ªÊí≠Âú®ÂàÜÊâãÂêéÁªßÁª≠Âú®‰∏â‰∏™Â∞èÊó∂ÁöÑÂπøÊí≠‰∏≠Êí≠Êä•Êñ∞Èóª | Pregnant New York news anchor continues to deliver news in three-hour broadcast after her water breaks
item.description:
Talk about breaking news.

A pregnant upstate New York news anchor broke the news that her water broke live on air ‚Äì and continued to host her show for another three hours, according to social media posts and reports.¬†

Olivia Jaquith, an anchor with WRGB, a CBS affiliate in Albany, made the announcement just before 6 a.m. on Wednesday that her water had broken moments before the newscast began, NBC News reported.

Jaquith and her co-anchor, Julia Dunn, went on Facebook Live just minutes before going on air to break the news and explain what had just happened.¬†

‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt April Fools, Olivia‚Äôs water broke ‚Äì in the newsroom, right?‚Äù Dunn asks.

‚ÄúIn the newsroom,‚Äù Jaquith confirms.¬†

Dunn hands the phone to Jaquith and tells her she needs to explain what‚Äôs going on.¬†

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on, this is my first time, I‚Äôm new here,‚Äù Jaquith jokes.

Then Jaquith explained that she felt some discomfort the day before and went to the doctors, where a monitor picked up a few contractions. When she came into work the following morning, her water broke in the bathroom, just a few minutes before going live on air.¬†

The jokes continued as Jaquith¬†‚Äì who said she was two days past her due date ‚Äì continued to labor on through the broadcast, cracking jokes with her colleagues during the entire three-hour run of the news show.¬†

‚ÄúWe do have some breaking news this morning. Literally, Olivia‚Äôs water has broke, and she is anchoring the news now in active labor,‚Äù Dunn said at the top of the show.

‚ÄúEarly labor. Early labor,‚Äù Jaquith added with a grin. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs not get carried away.‚Äù

Jaquith‚Äôs contractions were two minutes apart ‚Äì Dunn said they had been timing them.

‚ÄúNo, well, there was one, but it‚Äôs been a few minutes since then, so we‚Äôre still in good shape,‚Äù Jaquith said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to be here, and I‚Äôll stay on the desk for as long as I possibly can,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut if I disappear, that‚Äôs what‚Äôs going on.‚Äù

The broadcast staff had fun with Jaquith‚Äôs unusual situation.¬† A chyron at the top of the screen read: ‚ÄúDays Past Due Date: 2.‚Äù¬†

At one point, a headline at the bottom of the broadcast announced: ‚ÄúBaby Watch‚Äù and ‚ÄúHere Comes Baby P, Good Luck Olivia.‚Äù

Jaquith never seemed nervous or uncomfortable during the newscast, at one point asking the program‚Äôs meteorologist a cheeky question.

‚ÄúIf my baby does come today, Craig, how‚Äôs the weather looking?‚Äù

The weatherman joked about putting her over his shoulder and taking her to the hospital if things become urgent.¬†

Instead of a coffee break, Jaquith suggested that viewers take a ‚Äúwater break.‚Äù

On Thursday, the anchor announced that her baby boy ‚Äî her first child with her husband Tyn ‚Äî had arrived.

‚ÄúWhat a wild 24 hours! And now, baby boy is here,‚Äù she wrote on Instagram. ‚ÄúSoaking up kisses and cuddles for now, but will share updates soon.‚Äù
item.author: Daryl Khan
